chapter_title: Grassroots Democracy â€“ Part 3: Local Government in Urban Areas

questions.question_text: What are urban local bodies and what are their functions?
hints: Look at the definition in the 'Urban Local Bodies' section
Consider the range of responsibilities mentioned like infrastructure, garbage collection, tax collection

questions.question_text: Why are they important in governance and democracy?
hints: Think about participatory democracy and citizen empowerment
Consider how they bring governance closer to people

questions.question_text: Why is a city like Kolkata, Chennai or Mumbai more complex and diverse than a village or a town?
hints: Consider population density and diversity
Think about infrastructure and services required

questions.question_text: With your classmates, make a list of diverse communities residing in any city that you are familiar with. How many were you able to list? What else do you observe in the list?
hints: Consider different ethnic, religious, linguistic groups
Think about migrant communities and professions

questions.question_text: In Fig. 12.2 above, what similarities and differences do you notice between the Panchayati Raj system and the urban local government?
hints: Compare the pyramid structure shown in the figure
Look at the different levels in rural vs urban systems

questions.question_text: Can you think of four or five more actions that responsible citizens might take to help their area of the city?
hints: Think beyond waste segregation and reporting leaks
Consider community participation and civic duties

questions.question_text: Indore in Madhya Pradesh has been awarded the cleanest city in India under the Swachh Survekshan government scheme for seven years in a row. What could have been the role of Indore citizens in this achievement?
hints: Consider citizen participation in waste management
Think about following municipal guidelines and cooperation

questions.question_text: Select a few cities, from your State and from a few neighbouring States. These may include the city you live in or the city nearest to your town or village. How will you find out if they have a Nagar Panchayat, Municipal Council or Municipal Corporation? Draw a table with the names of the cities and the type of urban local body each of them has.
hints: Use population criteria: >10 lakhs = Municipal Corporation, 1-10 lakhs = Municipal Council, smaller = Nagar Panchayat
Check municipal websites or government portals

questions.question_text: How do urban local bodies fund their activities? (Hint: Look carefully at the pictures of the functions performed by Indore Municipal Corporation in Figure 12.4 on page 178.) Are some of them paid services?
hints: Look at services like property tax, water charges, trade licenses
Consider both tax revenue and user charges

questions.question_text: On your way to school, you and your friends notice that a water pipe is leaking. A lot of water is being wasted on account of the leak. What would you and your friends do in such a situation?
hints: Consider immediate reporting to authorities
Think about temporary measures to reduce wastage

questions.question_text: Invite a member of an urban local body near you to your class. Discuss with them their role and responsibilities. Prepare a set of questions to ask them so that the meeting is fruitful.
hints: Prepare questions about daily responsibilities
Ask about challenges and citizen interactions

questions.question_text: Discuss with adult members of your family and neighbourhood, and make a list of their expectations from the urban local bodies.
hints: Consider basic services like water, sanitation, roads
Think about transparency and responsiveness

questions.question_text: Make a list of characteristics of a good urban local body.
hints: Consider efficiency, transparency, accountability
Think about citizen participation and responsiveness

questions.question_text: What are the similarities and differences between the Panchayati Raj system in rural areas and the urban local bodies?
hints: Compare structure, functions, and citizen participation
Consider scale and complexity differences
